question.title: VS Code's java language server cannot detect java package
question.body:
I'm working on a Java project using Visual Studio Code, and I'm importing classes from the algs4.jar library , but VS code keeps showing package does not exist, even though:

  • The code compiles and runs fine .

  • algs4.jar is listed correctly under "Referenced Libraries" in the Java Projects panel.

  • My Java file (Arithmetic.java) is inside a source folder that is listed in java.project.sourcePaths.

  • I'm opening the root workspace folder (cs61b/) which contains everything, including:

    • .vscode/settings.json

    • library-sp25/algs4.jar

    • lab1/lab01/src/Arithmetic.java

Here's my .vscode/settings.json:

{
  "java.project.sourcePaths": [
    "lab1/lab01/src"
  ],
  "java.project.referencedLibraries": [
    "library-sp25/algs4.jar"
  ]
}

I 've already added path of the .jar library to the .vscode/settings.json file, and the libraries' also shown in java project manager. both the java file and algs4 package is recognised I tried switching java language server mode to standard, still doesn't work.

source codeï¼š

import edu.princeton.cs.algs4.StdIn;
/** Simple Arithmetic Class.
 * @author Josh Hug
 * */
public class Arithmetic {

    /** Computes product of two ints.
     * @param a Value 1
     * @param b Value 2
     * @return Product of a and b
     * */
    public static int product(int a, int b) {
        return a * b;
    }

    /** Computes sum of two ints (incorrectly).
     * @param a Value 1
     * @param b Value 2
     * @return Sum of a and b
     * */
    public static int sum(int a, int b) {
        return a * b;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println("Give me a number! (no decimals, please)");
        int num1 = StdIn.readInt();
        System.out.println("Give me another number! (still no decimals)");
        int num2 = StdIn.readInt();

        System.out.println("The product of " + num1 + " and " + num2 + " is: " + product(num1, num2));
        System.out.println("The sum of " + num1 + " and " + num2 + " is: " + sum(num1, num2));
    }
}

error message:

[{
    "resource": "/e:/coding/cs61b/lab1/lab01/src/Arithmetic.java",
    "owner": "_generated_diagnostic_collection_name_#1",
    "code": "errors(1): 1:8-1:11",
    "severity": 8,
    "message": "package edu.princeton.cs.algs4 does not exist",
    "startLineNumber": 1,
    "startColumn": 8,
    "endLineNumber": 1,
    "endColumn": 11,
    "origin": "extHost1"
}]

question_comments.body: @queeg It uses JDT-LS and hence parts of Eclipse's Java tooling (JDT-LS provides an Eclipse-like project model, the Eclipse compiler, debugging, etc though the things VSC has a UI for is very limited (and I don't know how many parts of JDT-core are actuallyavailablein JDT-LS). This here is a Java project without a build tool where referenced libraries refers to the classpath set by JDT-LS. Of course, it can also build Maven and Gradle projects (idk if VSC supports Ant).
I am wondering which build tool VS Code is based on. Ant, Maven, Gradle, Ivy ... there are lots but VS Code is an extra egg.
Have you tried restarting the Java language server? If that doesn't work, have you tried cleaning the Java language server workspace? Both can be done via the command palette.

@dan1st also, it's not just this particular algs4.jar that I cannot access, it seems to be that the language server can't recognise all the library files in my library folder. I've tried other files that import other libraries from the same folder and same thing happens.
@dan1st sure, it's got a bunch of .class files, I have edited and added the contents
Can you expand the content of edu.princeton.cs.algs4 in algs4.jar?
@WasabiThumbs "Referenced Libraries" comes from JDT-LS and refers to the libraries the language server uses.

I believe that in a Java-first IDE like IDEA you can pass libraries to the IDE like this and expect it to work, but it's hard to say with VSC. The referencedLibraries bit reads like an assertion to the language server that those libraries are referenced by the build script, and not a replacement for the actual build script.
